core_ideas.name: Cogito, ergo sum ('I think, therefore I am')
core_ideas.summary: Descartes’ foundational certainty: even if all else is doubted, the very act of doubting confirms the existence of the doubter.
discussion_hooks: Is self-awareness the only indubitable foundation for knowledge?
Can 'I think' exist without a self behind the thought?

core_ideas.name: Methodic Doubt
core_ideas.summary: Descartes proposed systematically doubting all beliefs to find a foundation of certainty on which to build reliable knowledge.
discussion_hooks: Can radical doubt be a constructive tool for modern inquiry?
What risks arise from doubting too much—or too little?

core_ideas.name: Mind-Body Dualism
core_ideas.summary: Descartes argued for a fundamental distinction between mind (res cogitans) and body (res extensa), setting the stage for modern debates on consciousness.
discussion_hooks: Are mind and body truly distinct substances—or two aspects of the same reality?
How has Descartes’ dualism shaped (or distorted) our understanding of self and world?

core_ideas.name: Clear and Distinct Ideas
core_ideas.summary: For Descartes, knowledge must be based on ideas that are clear (intellectually transparent) and distinct (unambiguously defined). These serve as the criteria for truth.
discussion_hooks: Can all meaningful knowledge be reduced to clear and distinct ideas?
What happens to complex truths that resist clarity?

core_ideas.name: God as the Guarantee of Truth
core_ideas.summary: Descartes believed that a perfect, non-deceptive God must exist and ensures the reliability of clear and distinct perceptions, anchoring knowledge in divine benevolence.
discussion_hooks: Can reason alone prove the existence and trustworthiness of God?
Does invoking God solve or merely shift the problem of certainty?

core_ideas.name: Innate Ideas
core_ideas.summary: Descartes posited that certain ideas (such as those of God, self, and mathematics) are innate—implanted by nature or God, not derived from experience.
discussion_hooks: Are some truths hardwired into human reason?
How does Descartes’ theory of innate ideas compare with modern cognitive science?

core_ideas.name: Mechanistic Physics
core_ideas.summary: Descartes proposed a mechanistic view of the physical universe: matter is extended substance governed by mathematical laws, excluding teleology from nature.
discussion_hooks: Did Descartes’ physics liberate science from metaphysics—or impose a new metaphysical dogma?
How does Cartesian mechanism relate to today's computational view of nature?

core_ideas.name: Cartesian Coordinate System
core_ideas.summary: Descartes merged algebra and geometry into analytical geometry, revolutionizing mathematics and laying the groundwork for the modern scientific method.
discussion_hooks: How did Descartes’ mathematical vision shape modern science?
Is the world more intelligible because we see it through mathematical eyes?

core_ideas.name: Ego-Centric Epistemology
core_ideas.summary: Descartes centered philosophy on the individual subject's capacity to know, setting the tone for modern epistemology and the 'problem of the external world.'
discussion_hooks: Did Descartes help emancipate the self—or imprison it within its own mind?
Can knowledge of the world begin within the self?

core_ideas.name: The Evil Demon Hypothesis
core_ideas.summary: To test the limits of certainty, Descartes imagined a powerful deceiver manipulating all his thoughts—posing the challenge of radical skepticism.
discussion_hooks: Is it possible to refute absolute skepticism without invoking metaphysics?
How does Descartes’ demon prefigure modern concerns about simulated or illusory reality?

perspectivism_framework.principle: While Descartes sought universal truths, his method begins from a radically first-person perspective—epistemic certainty rooted in individual introspection.
implications: Foundational knowledge must begin from within the subject’s own mind.
Truth must survive the harshest skepticism to be worthy of assent.
example_prompts: What do you know that cannot possibly be false?
Where in your own experience can doubt not reach?

aphorisms: The preservation of health should be the first study of one who is of sound mind.
It is not enough to possess a good mind; it must be applied.
The greatest minds are capable of the greatest vices as well as the greatest virtues.
Except our own thoughts, there is nothing absolutely in our power.
Doubt is the origin of wisdom.
To live without philosophizing is in truth the same as keeping the eyes closed without attempting to open them.
The reading of all good books is like a conversation with the finest minds of past centuries.
Divide each difficulty into as many parts as is feasible and necessary to resolve it.
